text:
Brainwriting (6-3-5)

Read your need statement in your learning journal. In this activity you will silently brainstorm design solution ideas for that need statement using the chart below.

First, write your name in the first row, then write down three design solution ideas in that row (under the headings "Idea 1," "Idea 2," and "Idea 3"). Keep the classroom quiet so everyone can have space to think.

Find a partner. Swap tables with your partner. Now you have your partner's table. Read the three ideas your partner came up with in the first row. Then, inspired by your partner's ideas, write your name in the second row (of your partner's table) and write down three more ideas in the second row. Try to read and write silently to give your classmates space to think. If you cannot understand something written in the table it is okay to talk quietly with your partner.

Find a new partner. Swap tables. Read their ideas. Write your name in the third row and write down three more ideas.

Keep swapping partners until you have filled the table. When you finish, your table will have your ideas in the first row and five additional rows with ideas from your partners.

Collaborative Sketching

Use the sketch boxes below to complete the following steps:

1. Take 3 minutes to sketch one design solution idea. You can come up with a completely new idea or start with one of your existing ideas and add more details in your sketch.

2. Explain your sketch to your partner. How does the design solution work? What are it's special features and details?

3. Swap sketches. Add on to your partner's sketch. (1) Sketch some of the special features and details based on your partner's description and (2) add something new to their sketch.

4. Explain the additions you made to your partner. How does the design solution work? What are it's special features and details?

-----

Complete this exercise again with a different design solution idea.

Design Heuristics

In this activity, you will use cards to help you transform your design solution ideas. Look over your design idea sketches and notes. Then read the two cards below. Choose one of the cards to use. Then use that card to modify one of your design solution ideas. Sketch your new idea in the sketch box below.

For example, I have an idea to make a watering chart for the school garden. I choose the card "use less material." I have the idea that I could use less paper if I make the watering chart on a half sheet of paper or if I make the chart online using a google chart. I decide to sketch the idea of an online watering chart.

Design Heuristics: Round 2

Look over your design idea sketches and notes. Then read the two cards below. Choose one of the cards to use. Then use that card to modify one of your design solution ideas. Sketch your new idea in the sketch box below.
